metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Bharat Nidhi Ltd. (formerly Bharat Bank Ltd.)

facts.text: Appellant took up service with respondent (then Bharat Bank Ltd.) with effect from July 1, 1944, as an Inspector at Bombay in the grade of Rs. 170-10-200-20-400.
Appellant was given three increments, first increment fell due as from October 1, 1945.
Appellant was given promotions on October 1, 1946, and on October 1, 1947.
Appellant was drawing Rs. 240 per month plus special allowance of Rs. 30 per month when discharged by respondent on August 5, 1949, on plea that he had become surplus.

Government of India, Ministry of Labour by Notification dated February 21, 1950, referred disputes between banks and employees to Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Calcutta; appellant's case heard therein.

Central Government Industrial Tribunal held on December 5, 1950, that order of discharge illegal; directed reinstatement and payment of arrears of salary and allowances from date of discharge, to be carried out within one month of publication on December 30, 1950.
Respondent appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal on January 30, 1951; Tribunal by decision dated September 25, 1951, upheld directions and dismissed appeal.
Respondent failed to implement decision despite appellant's letter dated October 10, 1951, intimating readiness to report for duty at Bombay and claiming arrears.
Appellant served notice on November 5, 1951, through solicitors, claiming Rs. 32,388 as compensation for pay till 55th year (May 4, 1960), Provident Fund, gratuity, exclusive of other claims.
Appellant made application to Government of India on February 22, 1952, for recovery under s.20(1) of Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950.
Government replied on May 13, 1952, advising revised application for arrears only and suggesting approach to Tribunal under s.20(2) for computation of reinstatement benefit.
Respondent (now Bharat Nidhi Ltd.) transferred banking business to Punjab National Bank Ltd. around March 1951, closed branches.

Respondent's letter dated April 3, 1952, stated appellant surplus due to transfer, gave two months' notice under s.19(6) Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, to terminate award and services; noted Delhi as only office.
Appellant's advocates replied on April 16, 1952, noting no response to prior letter, application under s.20(1) pending.
Respondent's letter dated May 10, 1952, reiterated appellant failed to join at Delhi, treated as evasion and absence from duty; notice effective April 9, 1952.
Respondent wrote to Government on June 28, 1952, stating arrears paid, appellant asked to resume duty but failed, considered absent.
Appellant filed petition on October 8, 1952, under s.20(2) for computation of Rs. 47,738 as money value of reinstatement benefit.
Respondent's written statement December 4, 1952: appellant violated instructions to join, forfeited rights; offered salary to June 19, 1952; award expired under s.19(3) ID Act.

Central Government Industrial Tribunal observed three aspects: (i) respondent's refusal to implement; (ii) appellant's failure to resume; (iii) relief/compensation considering bank ceased functioning; held for appellant on (i)(ii), awarded Rs. 1,000 under s.20(2) analogizing s.95 CPC.
Appellant appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal; respondent objected under s.7 as no substantial question of law; Tribunal dismissed appeal as incompetent on April 29, 1954.
Supreme Court granted special leave.
Industrial Tribunal found respondent guilty of unfair labour practice and victimization in award dated December 5, 1950.
Bank bye-laws: resignation/termination on one month's notice or pay in lieu; retirement at 55 years.

legal_issues.text: Whether the respondent refused to implement the award or subsequent decision by not taking appellant back in service.
Whether the appellant failed to resume duty despite being asked and thereby forfeited the right conferred by the award.
What relief or compensation in lieu of reinstatement the appellant is entitled to, considering circumstances including bank ceasing to function.
Method of computation in terms of money of the benefit of reinstatement under s.20(2) of the Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent refused to implement award; appellant ready and willing to join but not informed where to report.
Claim Rs. 32,388 (later Rs. 47,738) as compensation for pay, PF, gratuity till age 55 (May 4, 1960).
Computation on basis of: (i) full tenure to superannuation; (ii) damages for breach of contract; (iii) damages for breach of statutory duty/tort including special damages.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ordinary law of master and servant; Chitty on Contracts

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant flagrant violation by not joining duty despite instructions; forfeited reinstatement rights.
Offered salary upto June 19, 1952; award in force only one year under s.19(3) ID Act, 1947, terminated.
Transfer to Punjab National Bank Ltd., closure of branches; only 10 employees absorbed; others got notice pay and retrenchment compensation; no obligation on PNB.

court_reasoning.text: Findings on refusal to implement and appellant's readiness upheld; no reason to disturb after perusing correspondence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant ready and willing, not guilty of default.

court_reasoning.text: Benefit of reinstatement not term of contract; effect is to set aside wrongful dismissal, reinstate under original terms; computation under s.20(2) not damages for breach but value of benefit from reinstatement date, considering tenure, termination possibilities, retrenchment, superannuation, etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not analogous to breach of contract, tort, or declaration of continuance; purpose of s.20(2) is to monetize non-monetary benefit for recovery.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent's transfer/closure not availed in correspondence; insisted on joining at Delhi till June 1952; cannot raise now.
Reject s.95 CPC analogy; not compensation for injury like arrest/injunction.

Bye-laws allow one month notice/pay in lieu, retirement at 55; but unfair practice finding prevents easy termination; future tribunal could reinstate on dispute; estimate Rs. 12,500 considering all factors, present value.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Impossible with mathematical exactitude; reasonable estimate.

holdings.text: Money value of reinstatement benefit computed at Rs. 12,500.
First two issues concluded in favor of appellant.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collier v. Sunday Referee Publishing Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages for wrongful dismissal under specific term contract measured by salary lost subject to mitigation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Salt v. Power Plant Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Damages for life employment consider possibilities of termination, present value, death, etc.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Award duration one year; notice to terminate award/services.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Recovery of money due; computation of money value of benefit by tribunal; appeal competence.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Incorrectly analogized by tribunal for compensation on non-implementation.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; decisions of Labour Appellate Tribunal (April 29, 1954) and Industrial Tribunal award set aside; appellant awarded Rs. 12,500 as computation of money value of reinstatement benefit under s.20(2).

key_quotes.text: "The monetary value of the benefits of such reinstatement is therefore to be computed not on the basis of a breach of the contract of employment nor on the basis of a tort alleged to have been committed by the employer."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies basis for computation under s.20(2).

key_quotes.text: "We have come to the conclusion that having regard to all the circumstances of the case it would be reasonable to compute the benefit of reinstatement which was awarded to the appellant at an amount of Rs. 12,500."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Such computation has relation only to the date from which the reinstatement of the workman has been ordered under the terms of the award and would have to be made by the Industrial Tribunal having regard to all the circumstances of the case."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope and method of computation.
